Safeguards
	Deprivation of liberty: authorisation of arrangements enabling care andtreatment
		The Mental Capacity Act 2005 is amended as follows.
		In section 4A (restriction on deprivation of liberty) for subsection (5)substitute—
		D may deprive P of liberty if, by doing so, D is carrying out arrangementsauthorised under Schedule AA1 (arrangements enabling the care and treatment ofpersons who lack capacity).”
		After section 4B insert—
		“4CCarrying out of authorised arrangements giving rise to deprivation ofliberty
			This section applies to an act that a person (“D”) does in carrying outarrangements authorised under Schedule AA1.
			D does not incur any liability in relation to the act that would not havebeen incurred if the cared-for person—
				had had capacity to consent in relation to D doing the act, and
				had consented to D doing the act.
			Nothing in this section excludes a person’s civil liability for loss ordamage, or a person’s criminal liability, resulting from that person’snegligence in doing the act.
			Paragraph 31 of Schedule AA1 applies if an authorisation ceases to haveeffect in certain cases.
			“Cared-for person” has the meaning given by paragraph 2(1) of thatSchedule.”
			Before Schedule 1 insert the Schedule AA1 set out in Schedule 1 to thisAct.
	Deprivation of liberty: authorisation of steps necessary for life-sustaining treatment or vital act
		For section 4B of the Mental Capacity Act 2005 substitute—
		“4BDeprivation of liberty necessary for life-sustaining treatment orvital act
			If Conditions 1 to 4 are met, D is authorised to take steps which deprive Pof liberty.
			Condition 1 is that the steps—
				are wholly or partly for the purpose of giving P life-sustaining treatmentor doing any vital act, or
				consist wholly or partly of giving P life-sustaining treatment or doing anyvital act.
			A vital act is any act which the person doing it reasonably believes to benecessary to prevent a serious deterioration in P’s condition.
			Condition 2 is that the steps are necessary in order to give the life-sustaining treatment or do the vital act.
			Condition 3 is that D reasonably believes that P lacks capacity to consentto D taking the steps.
			Condition 4 is that—
				subsection (7) applies, or
				there is an emergency.
			This subsection applies if—
				a decision relevant to whether D is authorised to deprive P of liberty isbeing sought from the court, or
				a responsible body is carrying out functions under Schedule AA1 with a viewto determining whether to authorise arrangements that give rise to adeprivation of P’s liberty.
			In subsection (7) it does not matter—
				whether the decision mentioned in paragraph (a) relates to the stepsmentioned in subsection (1);
				whether the arrangements mentioned in paragraph (b) include those steps.
			There is an emergency if D reasonably believes that—
				there is an urgent need to take the steps mentioned in subsection (1) inorder to give the life-sustaining treatment or do the vital act, and
				it is not reasonably practicable before taking those steps—
				to make an application for P to be detained under Part 2 of the MentalHealth Act,
				to make an application within subsection (7)(a), or
				to secure that action within subsection (7)(b) is taken.”
	Powers of the court to determine questions
		After section 21 of the Mental Capacity Act 2005 insert—
		“Powers of the court in relation to Schedule AA1
			ZAPowers of court in relation to Schedule AA1
				This section applies where an authorisation under Schedule AA1—
					has effect, or
					is to have effect from a date specified under paragraph 28 of thatSchedule.
				The court may determine any question relating to—
					whether Schedule AA1 applies to the arrangements, or whether theauthorisation conditions are met;
					what period the authorisation has effect for;
					what the authorisation relates to.
				If the court determines a question under subsection (2), the court may makean order—
					varying or terminating the authorisation;
					directing the responsible body to vary the authorisation.
				Where the court makes an order under subsection (3) the court may make anorder about a person’s liability for anything done in carrying out thearrangements before the variation or termination.
				An order under subsection (4) may, in particular, exclude a person fromliability.
				“Authorisation conditions” has the meaning given by paragraph 13 ofSchedule AA1.”
Code of practice etc
	Deprivation of liberty: code of practice
		Section 42 of the Mental Capacity Act 2005 (codes of practice) is amendedas follows.
		After subsection (1) insert—
			“(1A)Guidance about what kinds of arrangements for enabling the care ortreatment of a person fall within paragraph 2(1)(b) of Schedule AA1 must beincluded in the code, or one of the codes, issued under subsection (1).”
		After subsection (2) insert—
		“(2A)Before the end of each review period the Lord Chancellor must—
			review each code for the guidance of persons exercising functions underSchedule AA1, and
			lay a report of the review before Parliament.
			But this does not affect the Lord Chancellor’s functions under subsection (2).
			(2B)A review period is—
			in relation to the first review, the period of 3 years beginning with theday on which this subsection comes into force, and
			in relation to subsequent reviews, each period of 5 years beginning withthe day on which the report of the previous review was laid beforeParliament.”
		In subsection (3) after “preparation” insert “, review”.
General
	Consequential provision etc
		The Secretary of State may by regulations make provision that isconsequential on any provision made by this Act.
		Regulations under this section—
			may make different provision for different purposes or areas;
			may amend, repeal or revoke any provision made by or under an Act passedbefore this Act or in the same Session.
		The power to make regulations under this section is exercisable bystatutory instrument.
		Regulations under this section that repeal or amend a provision of an Actmay not be made unless a draft of the statutory instrument containing them hasbeen laid before Parliament and approved by a resolution of each House ofParliament.
		Any other regulations under this section are subject to annulment inpursuance of a resolution of either House of Parliament.
		Schedule 2 makes minor and consequential amendments.
	Extent, commencement and short title
		This Act extends to England and Wales only.
		This section, and section 5 except subsection (6), come into force on theday this Act is passed.
		The other provisions of this Act come into force—
			for the purpose only of enabling the exercise of any power to makeregulations, on the day this Act is passed;
			for all other purposes, on whatever day the Secretary of State appoints byregulations.
		Different days may be appointed for different purposes or different areas.
		The Secretary of State may by regulations make transitional or savingprovision in connection with the coming into force of any provision of thisAct.
		Regulations under subsection (5) may make different provision for differentpurposes or different areas.
		The power to make regulations under this section is exercisable bystatutory instrument.
		This Act may be cited as the Mental Capacity (Amendment) Act 2019.
